ResponsesInList.Title: LDAP filters (Moodle 3.6)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, I hope you can help me. I need to filter users within an Active Directory. The filter they send us is: (| (& (objectCategory = person) (objectSid = *) (! samAccountType: 1.2.840.113556.1.4.804: = 3)) (& (objectCategory = person) (! objectSid = *)) (& (objectCategory = group ))) Reading in the forum Emma gives the following example: (| (& (objectClass = user) (! (objectClass = computer)) (memberOf = cn = MoodleUser, ou = people, dc = yourdomain, dc = com))) How should I do it? I'm trying different alternatives and they don't work. Only if I leave by default objectClass = * loads all users but without filtering and I need only the corresponding ones to be displayed. Thank you Gonzalo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LDAP filters (Moodle 3.6)
ResponsesInList.Text: Your filter is confusing - can you explain in non-filter speak what you are using to identify the users that you want to pull?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LDAP filters (Moodle 3.6)
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Gonzalo, The syntax for the LDAP filters is documented in RFC 4515 , using an Augmented Backus-Naur Form grammar (ABNF for short). If we deconstruct your filters using that grammar, we can see what those filters are doing, and then you can check if what the filters are doing is what you wanted them to do or not (and then build the filters that do what you want). Let's have a look at the first filter. I have arranged it slightlty differently to see what parts it's composed of, and how they compose. But appart from indentation, it's exactly the same filter you posted (except for AND filter blocks, that will appear as "(&" instead of "(&", as the Moodle forum filtering is munging the syntax): 
```text
(| 

   (&
      (objectCategory = person)
      (objectSid = *)
      (! samAccountType: 1.2.840.113556.1.4.804: = 3)
   )

   (&
      (objectCategory = person)
      (! objectSid = *)
   )

   (&
      (objectCategory = group)
   )

)
```
 If we have a look a the RFC 4514 ABNF grammar, we can intepret the pieces. This is an "OR" filter block: 
```text
(|
    one or more "filtercomp" elements
)
```
 meaning that the filter block will match if ANY of the "filtercomp" elements match. This is an "AND" filter block: 
```text
(&
    one or more "filtercomp" elements
)
```
 meaning that the filter block will match if ALL of the "filtercomp" elements match. This is a "NOT" filter block: 
```text
(!
    a "filter" element (i.e., a whole filter, possibly composed of AND,  OR or NOT filter blocks, etc.)
)
```
 meaning that the filter block will match if "filter" element DOESN'T match (or viceversa). Finally, there are the simple filtering elements (called `item` in the ABNF grammar). The criteria used to filter (match) based on attributes and values of the LDAP objects to filer. Your first filter includes such items as `(objectCategory = person)` , `(objectSid = *)` and `(! samAccountType: 1.2.840.113556.1.4.804: = 3)` . They respectively match if the `objectCaterory` attribute has the `person` value, the `objectSid` attribute has any value ( `*` is the wildcard value), and the if the `samAccountType` attribute DOESN'T have any of its two lower bits set. This last one is a bit tricky, as it uses `extensibleMatch` filtering rules, which are complex things. In this case, samAccountType attribute specifies if a given ActiveDirectory object is a user object, a group object, a machine object, etc. Users and groups don't have the two lower bits sets, but other kind of objects do (see https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/adschema/a-samaccounttype for details). So if we put those things together in the first filter block: 
```text
   (&
      (objectCategory = person)
      (objectSid = *)
      (! samAccountType: 1.2.840.113556.1.4.804: = 3)
   )
```
 we can conclude that this AND filter block will only match those LDAP objects whose objectCategory is `person` AND whose objectSid is any value, and whose samAccountType is NOT of type `machine` or `non security group` , `trust account` , etc. This basically matches any LDAP object that is considered a `person` in Active Directory. But note that Active Directory may consider objects to be of `person` category for other things besides user accounts. The second filter block: 
```text
   (&
      (objectCategory = person)
      (! objectSid = *)
   )
```
 matches any object whose objectCategory is `person` (same as above), but whose objectSid value is NOT any value. The only way to fullfil this last criteria is by not having a value at all for the objectSid attribute at all, which I don't think is possible in Active Directory, as I think this is a mandatory attribute. If I'm right, that means this filter block will never match anything at all. The third filter block: 
```text
   (&
      (objectCategory = group)
   )
```
 matches any objects whose objectCaterory is `group` , without any additional criteria. So you will probably get all the groups (both security and distribution groups) from the contexts you specified in you Moodle LDAP configuration. Moodle expects the filter to return users, not groups. So this part of the filter should be removed. Finally, if we put everything together, the filter will match any LDAP object that mathces EITHER the first filter block, OR the second filter block OR the third filter block. If we have a look at the second filter you posted (allegedly from Emma Richardson): 
```text
(|

   (&
      (objectClass = user)
      (! (objectClass = computer))
      (memberOf = cn = MoodleUser, ou = people, dc = yourdomain, dc = com)
   )

)
```
 we see that it is matching if (the objectClass attribute is `user` ) AND (the objectClass IS NOT `computer` ) AND (the memberOf attribute is `cn = MoodleUser, ou = people, dc = yourdomain, dc = com` ). So basically, any object that is a user account (but not a machine account) that belongs to the group whose distinguised name is `cn=MoodleUser, ou=people, dc=yourdomain, dc=com` . You will not probably have such a group in your Active Directory domain , so the filter will not match any user at all, and Moodle will not find any user at all.

```text

```
 
```text

```
 
```text
 $user->password = hash_internal_user_password($value);
```
 

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NTLM not working with moodle 3.4 and IIS 8.5
ResponsesInList.Text: Unfortunately I don't have a working environment to compare this with but the first four lines of the first excerpt indicate that the environment isn't configured in line with the documentation. Line 1 is a request on port 80 for the Moodle home page being rejected by IIS as unauthenticated with the response code 401 Unauthorized . Line 2 is IE automatically sending the NTLM authentication for its user and being redirected to port 443 for HTTPS access with response code 303 See Other . Line 3 is IE following that redirect to the HTTPS site but since HTTPS and HTTP count as different sites it again gets rejected by IIS as authenticated with 401 Unauthorized . Line 4 is IE again sending the NTLM authentication and finally getting the Moodle home page with a 200 OK response. The Moodle documentation for NTLM single sign-on says to configure the file / auth/ldap/ntlmsso_magic.php for authenticated access but these lines indicate that access to /index.php has also been configured in this way, thus the unexpected 401 responses. Maybe this is something you've done deliberately and maybe it doesn't actually affect the issue but it's worth looking into. You may have inadvertently configured the whole Moodle folder for authenticated access.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What's the best way to remove old users?
ResponsesInList.Text: There is another question behind "deleting" users. In Moodle 1.9 the users were not "deleted" from the database, they were only marked as "deleted". This prevented new students with the same name as someone who left our university some years ago and was supposed to be "deleted" to have the same eMail-Address. The same was still true, after i switched manual authorization to LDAP auth, using our active directory servers. Not to be confused with LDAP-Synchronization. With Moodle 2, I know there is a new option to only "deactivate" users, besides "deleting" users. But I am not sure if "delete" still means only marking as deleted or since Moodle 2 the user records are really purged out of the users table. Anyway, as we had also a lot of students coming again to take courses even after they left our university, I was able to unmark them directly in the database of Moodle 1.9 (no courses and grades were deleted, and so the account simply was revived) - but with Moodle 2 I guess that "deleting" will remove any courses and grades associated with the user. So everything would be lost, even if the user-account were only marked to be deleted. That's why in Moodle 2 I adopted still the behaviour to never delete users, but only suspend them. This way, if a student comes back, we will be able to activate his Moodle-account, unless we had reused the same account for another student with the same name and eMail in our Active-Directory in between. In which case we have to activate the Moodle-account after having checked if this is still the same person. If it is not the same person, we activate but unenroll from all courses before we let the student/teacher log into Moodle. And a new student/teacher with the same name as another active student/teacher gets the same name with a number added to his/her lastname, like firstname.lastname01 Rosario

ResponsesInList.Text: I never used LDAP synchronisation and course creation. I thought it too risky to manage such things in the Active Directory and have synchronisation on this. In our big university there are also too many people and too many automatic processes involved to keep a good health there. So I only used LDAP authentication. This does merely a lookup of the user and his/her password in our Active-Directory. If you need settings, I could give it here, although they should already be in the forums here more than once. For automatic course creation I wrote uploadusersandcourses.php, you can find in these forums. With that code I could reflect our real workflow (teachers can ask for courses in another web-application, including the students they want to enrol - the file gets written to a windows-share I have mounted on my Moodle linux server - a nightly cron job fires uploadusersandcourses.php which creates the courses, enrolls the given people and writes back a file with courses created with success to the same share - next day another file is written to the share containing any new courses or if something went wrong the file might also contain once again courses not created yet. As for student synchronization, I never deleted, nowadays I would suspend and activate again, preferring some hand-work to do over an automatic synchronization. LDAP-Synch should be scheduled to run once a night during the normal Moodle- Cron -Jobs. If you could speed up to synch e.g. on every hour, has to be checked in the LDAP-Synch-Module-Settings. Just not to confuse things. There is an LDAP AUTH Module, which is what I used. So after a bit more tinkering I found that if I added 'Domain Users', i.e. everyone into the group IIS_IUSRS then the automatic SSO works for all users. However, I'm still not convinced about the security of this and can only assume this is something to do with the php trying run under the user trying to log in rather than the webserver? (app pool identity?) I haven't played with IIS 7.5 yet, but up to IIS 7.0, the access to a protected page file (i.e., one configured not to allow anonymous access to) is controlled by the NTFS permissions of the file (and the permissions of the folders up in the path of the file). So as long as 'Users'[*] group (which contains both machine local users and domain-wide users, by default) has read permission and execute permission on the file that should work. [*] Replace 'Users' group with any security group you want to use to control access to that file (page). So I block permissions inheritance on that file (copying the permissions from the parent folder) and add the 'Users' group (if it's not already there) with read and execute permissions. I also completely remove IIS_IUSRS permissions on the file (only on that particular file), although I'm pretty sure there's no need for it once you remote 'Allow Anonymous Access' setting from the file in IIS settings. That should be enough (it certainly is with IIS 6.0 and 7.0). Saludos.
Iñaki.

This was the first question, then I have to know how to configure Samba configuration files. The above documentation is not very detailed. Sorry but I'm a beginner. Another problem is that I haven't Administrator account in the Active Directory (Join operation seems to require this), then I have to know all steps in detail before communicating all I need to System Administrators (for example network/domain operations). ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Samba on linux for NTLM Single Sign On
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mirco, the documentation on how to configure Samba is not very detailed because it focuses on the Moodle configuration side. You want to configure your CentOS server as a Samba AD Member server. The Samba documentation on how to do this can be found at https://wiki.samba.org/index.php/Setup_a_Samba_AD_Member_Server That documentation still asumes certain familiarity with Unix and Active Directory administration though. Regarding your second question, yes, you need an Active Directory domain account with "Add machine accounts" privilege (it's something like that, I'm going by memory). By default Domain Administrators have that privilege, but it can be assigned to other accounts (e.g., accounts in the "Account Operators" group get that privilege too). So you probably want to do all this hand in hand (i.e. sitting side by side) with one of your Active Directory administrators.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error using secure LDAP
ResponsesInList.Text:
I don't know anything about CAS authentication, but in general with LDAP authentication I've found it's easiest to turn off certificate verification for LDAPS by adding/editing /etc/openldap/ldap.conf to include the following entry: 
```text
TLS_REQCERT allow
```
 As general best practice you'd want to verify certificates but I often find that LDAP server certs aren't so easy to verify. However if you've already configured OpenLDAP to accept the LDAP server's certificate and your ldapsearch is working via LDAPS then I wouldn't expect this to be a problem. It's probably still worth trying, one thing I've had in the past is configuring OpenLDAP just for my user but Moodle running as Apache won't see that configuration.

ResponsesInList.Title: Unconfirmed users not being deleted by cron task because of a bug
ResponsesInList.Text: We have recently noticed that unconfirmed users are not being deleted by the corresponding cron task. Our database was showing more than one hundred users with confirmed = 0, deleted = 0 since our upgrade from Moodle 2.7. Unfortunately, this prevents them to create a new account, because email addresses are already registered. We have checked the code in lib/classes/task/delete_unconfirmed_users_task.php and we think we have found the bug in the SQL query that retrieves the users to be deleted: `$rs = $DB->get_recordset_sql ("SELECT * FROM {user} WHERE confirmed = 0 AND firstaccess > 0 AND firstaccess < ? AND deleted = 0", array($cuttime));` ($cuttime is current time - deleteunconfirmed threshold, 7 days by default.) All these unconfirmed users have firstaccess = 0 in database, because login/signup.php sets $user->firstaccess = 0 when the account is created. This way the AND condition is never matched. And this didn’t happen before upgrading because in Moodle 2.7 login/signup.php set $user->firstaccess = time(), i. e. account creation time, not zero. If you are experiencing this problem too, could you please have a look at the tracker and vote for this bug to be fixed? [MDL-54106] Delete unconfirmed users not working because firstaccess == 0

ResponsesInList.Title: LDAP User Lookup Settings problem in 1.8
ResponsesInList.Text: Has anyone using Moodle 1.8 notice the problem with the Member Attribute and the Member Attribute uses dn fields. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LDAP User Lookup Settings problem in 1.8
ResponsesInList.Text:
Yup! Absolutely true. I don't use these field myself, but just checked them in a test setup I have at hand and you are right. I'll have a look at it and try to track the bug down. Ok, that was easy. There is a small bug in .../auth/ldap/config.html. At line 231 you have: 
```text
<input name="memberattribute" id="memberattribute_isdn" type="text" size="30" value="<?php echo $config->memberattribute_isdn?>" />
```
 and you should change it to: 
```text
<input name="memberattribute_isdn" id="memberattribute_isdn" type="text" size="30" value="<?php echo $config->memberattribute_isdn?>" />
```
 That should do it. Saludos. Iñaki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.2 on Linux and NTLM
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you specified the correct Subnet details in the LDAP server settings? They have to be correct or the SS will not work. And it can be quite tricky to get the right subnet combination if you're on a big complex network. Make sure that the computer that you're testing it on is part of the subnet that you specify. Also, make sure you understand what SSO means! It means that the user will be logged into Moodle as the user that is logged into the COMPUTER from where the Moodle site is being accessed. ResponsesInList.Title: LDAP 2307 Authentication Module
ResponsesInList.Text: I ran into a problem in setting up our instance of Moodle while trying to get the LDAP authentication module to work completely. While I had no problems pointing it to our directory server and having users authenticate, I ran into problems with the automatic granting of course creator status. Digging into the code, I found that the current LDAP authentication module expects that the user's LDAP object contains attributes that specify the groups of which a user is a member. Our directory is set up slightly differently: group objects contain attributes that list the members of the group. This is apparently a fairly common way of organizing a directory, at least to those of us that come from the Unix and NIS universe (it's exactly the same concept as the Unix /etc/passwd and /etc/group files). In order to make creator status work with our directory, I wrote a new LDAP module based on the current one, but with a significantly altered auth_iscreator() function that looks up the group objects that contain attributes listing the currently logged in user (I also added the helper function auth_ldap_get_grouplist()). As our account management is done entirely outside the scope of Moodle, I also removed the user creation, activation, and disabling functions of the original LDAP module. Rather than make these changes to the original LDAP module, I thought that the groups structure represented a fundamental enough conceptual departure to warrant a completely separate module, at least to start out. (I certainly wouldn't be adverse to folding the two back together at some point.) The new module is called ldap2307, after the RFC number that contains this directory structure specification. I consider this module to be completely functional and stable, however it has had a limited testing environment. I have tested it in Moodle v1.1.1 and the current 1.2 beta against a Sun ONE directory server, and a colleague has tested it against OpenLDAP. We've found no problems with the code as it currently stands, although it's entirely possible that you'll have a local configuration that exposes a "gotcha". In the attached ZIP file, there is the ldap2307 authentication module and two language files: auth.php.new and auth.php.diff. The .new is a complete version of the lang/en/auth.php file with text for this module added. The .diff file is a "diff" against the original lang/en/auth.php file in Moodle v1.2 beta; you can apply it to your version with the Unix "patch" command.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Upload users -- type?
ResponsesInList.Text: I would say that the type1 to type5 fields are for backward compatibility. Prior to Moodle 1.7, roles were fixed (Editing Teacher, Student, Non-editing teacher), so they could have numeric codes (1, 2, 3). Sarting with Moodle 1.7, the aforementioned roles were still there (they consititute "predefined" roles) but you could also define new roles -- in fact, an open-ended number of new roles like Parent. It would be impossible to assign universal numeric codes to such roles. Instead, he role names themselves must be used (use the roles' "short name"). The upload format lets you upload up to five roles for each user (role1 in course1, role2 in course2, etc.) and possibly even in a group context (role1 in group1 of course1, role2 in group2 of course2). If you have not defined any new roles and are only using the predefined roles, go ahead and use the type fields. If I were you I would experiment. Create a short sample upload file, login to demo.moodle.org as admin, upload your file and see how it works.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Preventing the creation of new accounts
ResponsesInList.Text: You can also modify Moodle to not accept logins for users who are not in the database . This is a hack but it will work for any authentication mode, so in some way it is a cleaner solution for you. To accomplish this, open the moodle/lib/moodlelib.php file and find function authenticate_user_login(). There, after the first "if" block, insert the following: if (! $user->id) { return false; // no go for new users } Then in file moodle/lang/en/moodle.php find string 'invalidlogin' and modify it accordingly. For example: Invalid login, please try again. Note: if you are not a registered user on this site, you must contact Moodle Administrator to create a new signup. Of course, you need to do this in every language pack you use.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: windows adfs/saml2 auth help
ResponsesInList.Text: It looks like you've successfully authenticated with AD FS but Moodle isn't getting any attributes returned. From memory you have to configure "claims" for different attributes in AD FS for the "relying party", i.e. your Moodle site. The attributes you'd normally want to transfer are the username (userPrinicipalName or UPN), first name (givenName), last name (surname) and email address (email). Have you configured these attributes in the claim in AD FS? Can you add a screenshot of the attributes in the claim rule so we can check? There are some notes in the auth_saml2 plugin docs which may help. This problem looks a bit like issue 1 except that no attributes are returned. Any further debugging output you can include by following these docs will help troubleshoot the issue.

ResponsesInList.Title: same login account on OpenLDAP and Active Directory
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, I have successfully configured two authentication systems (OpenLDAP and Active Directory from two different servers) on the same moodle build. I have a question say: 1. There's an account called "user1" exists on my openldap DB 2. There's also an account called "MyDomain\user1" exists on my AD So, what would happened if someone logon to my moodle with username "user1"? which authenticating servers will "listen" to? (OpenLDAP? AD?) or the whole authenticating process depends on the userid? Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: same login account on OpenLDAP and Active Directory
ResponsesInList.Text: It depends on whether the user account already exists or not. If it doesn't, then Moodle will check the authentication plugins in the defined order. So it will check the first one, and if the password matches, it will create the user and store the authentication plugin used to validate that user. If the passwords don't match (but a user with that name actually exists in that ldap server ), Moodle will refuse the login saying that either the username or the password are wrong. If the user doesn't exist in the first ldap server it will try with the second and apply the same logic. Once the users are created, they'll always use 'their' ldap server (the one that was stored in their first login). Saludos, Iñaki.

ResponsesInList.Title: "Linked Gmail Accounts" solve the no-email address problem?
ResponsesInList.Text: Sign Me Up! The Elementary Email Solution: Linked Gmail Accounts Kim Cofino writes: One of my biggest stumbling blocks as I’ve switched gears from middle to elementary school is individual e-mail accounts for the students. Back in middle school, I could always count on every student having their own e-mail account. Even if, for some strange reason, one or two students didn’t have one, I could just ask them to sign up for one before the next class and it would be done. Alas, nothing is quite that easy at the elementary level…. In our case, for lower elementary students, we really only need each student to have an individual, permanent, e-mail address to sign up for other services (not to actually send and receive e-mail). So, in order to get our second grade class up and running with Ning accounts for our Global Village project (which, of course, require a consistent e-mail address for log in purposes - no mailenator for us), and in preparation for all of our Global Communication Center projects, I spent less than an hour today solving my problem, thanks to Gmail. Basically, Gmail allows you to create subsidiary accounts linked to an individual Gmail account. Check out this great screencast demonstrating how to create linked Gmail accounts that Alec Courosa made with Jing earlier today (I need to start getting the kids to make screencasts with Jing next - what a great way to create tutorials!). Basically, this means that one teacher can have 20 permanent e-mail accounts that are all delivered into one teacher e-mail account. Therefore, if the teacher account is teacher@gmail.com, all you have to do is add a “+studentname” before the @ symbol to make a linked account. Therefore mail sent to teacher+studentname@gmail.com will go straight to teacher@gmail.com. Of course, given that Gmail terms and conditions require users to be over 18, we did send out a permission slip to all parents to get their formal approval that we create these linked accounts. Continue reading at http://mscofino.edublogs.org/2007/10/18/sign-me-up-the-elementary-email-solution-linked-gmail-accounts/ -- Art

We are analyzing the problem and it seems that the problem is due to the hash algorithm used for storing the passwords. Following the use case: If the hash algorithm for the stored password is $2y$04, the user cannot login and he has to change the password (even if the password is still valid). ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Removing users via LDAP
ResponsesInList.Text:
Suspended users are actually assigned the 'nologin' authentication method. The net effect is that the LDAP authentication plugin doesn't touch them at all while deleting users, as it can't know for sure they were LDAP users before (e.g, they could have been suspended by the ext DB authentication plugin). So you'd need to 'revive' them first (re-assigning them to the LDAP auth plugin) and then delete them. Saludos.
Iñaki.

Hummm, I've just tested with a single account that I previously edited to set 'No login' as its authentication method, and it's been deleted successfully. If you filter the accounts but just add one, does your Moodle setup delete it? (just in case there's a bug when dealing with many users at once; I'm shooting in the dark here). On the other hand, if all of your 'No login' users were LDAP users before, and you have access to your database, you can also execute the following SQL sentence: 
```text
UPDATE mdl_user SET auth='ldap' WHERE auth='nologin' AND deleted=0;
```
 This will make your suspended users 'alive' and the next time you run your LDAP sync script they will get deleted. Saludos.
Iñaki.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, i am a new to moodle, only been using it two days. i am trying to use ldap authentication and i was just wondering what the warning was about not having the php ldap module installed, and how i go about solving this. i would be gratefull for all the help i can.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PHP LDAP module not installed
ResponsesInList.Text: I am a helpdesk administrator for the local school district, and I have already had the same problem, below is the documentation I wrote to accomplish this. Documentation for implementing the LDAP libraries into a compliation of PHP 1. Download Windows Binary Zip Package of PHP Version. Included in this Zip package are several folders. 2. Copy entire contets of 'dlls' to the System32 Folder 3. Make a folder entitled 'phpextensions' on the hard drive 4. Copy entire contets of 'extensions' to the 'phpextensions' folder on the hard drive 5. Open the php.ini file. It can be found in the windows base folder. 6 If GD, Scroll to step 10 7. Scroll down to a section entitled 'Paths and Directories' 8. There are two lines that read: ; Directory in which the loadable extensions (modules) reside. extension_dir = "/extensions" 9. Replace /extensions with 'c:\phpextensions' (The folder we made in step 3.) 10. Scroll down to a section entitled 'Dynamic Extensions' 11. There will be a list of extensions commented out with semi-colons, directly above that, add the line '--with-ldap' This is the GD switch that tells PHP to use the GD libraries. 12. Scroll down to a line that is commented out by a semi-colon that reads: ;extension=php_ldap.dll 13. Uncomment out that line by removing the semi-colon so it reads like: extension=php_ldap.dll 14. Save file and reload phpinfo.php script. 15. Open the Zip package of the PHP compilation and copy the entire contents over the PHP root directory. Over-write all files. 16. If phpinfo.php does not exist, create a text file and put the following line in: <?php phpinfo(); ?> 17. Save file as 'phpinfo.php' and place in root directory of web server (where php scripts are hosted) 18. Open file from web browser, and scroll down to a table that is headed by 'ldap', if the table exists, the LDAP libraries have been successfully compiled.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ldap synch not working
ResponsesInList.Text:
Assuming your PHP installation is at c:\php, and that there is a php.exe file inside that directory, and that your php.ini file is inside that directory too, and that your Moodle installation is at c:\inetpub\moodle, you just need to setup a scheduled task that runs the command: 
```text
c:\\php\\php.exe -c c:\\php\\php.ini -d memory_limit=256M -f c:\\inetpub\\moodle\\auth\\ldap\\auth_ldap_sync_users.hpp
```
 Make sure you use the right paths in you server. And use the schedule you see fit for your setup (running it once a day is quite usual, more than twice a day is overkill in my humble opinion). Saludos. Iñaki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Integrating moodle with other internal systems
ResponsesInList.Text: Sakina, How you do this would depend on a number of factors, some of which are: the web services or other API available in the course booking system where the integration code will live - Moodle, course reg system, separate application (i.e. some form of middleware) Possible scenario: user books a course on the course booking site when they "finish", they are sent to the moodle site on login to Moodle, their moodle enrolments are checked against their bookings on the cousre booking site any missing enrolments are created in moodle note, this assumes that the courses have been created and are available in Moodle before they are made bookable from the booking site If you decide to write the integration code on the Moodle side, you should implement it as a plugin (or a set of plugins). At all costs, avoid hacking core code. Hacking core will cause you a lot of grief in future. If you decide to write the integration code on the external site and call Moodle's web services API to register/enrol usrers into Moodle, you'll find the API documentation at http://your.moodle.url/admin/webservice/documentation.php helpful In terms of minimum information required by Moodle to register a user, those are: username, email, firstname and lastname. In order to enrol in a course, minimum requirements are userid, the role id, and the contextid - those terms may not mean anything to you right now, but you'll become familiar with them once you start developing your integration. Hope that helps. Muyi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Login via an external site
ResponsesInList.Text: Here are the key pieces from what I used to implement this.  These are copy / paste snippets from our authentication module.  Note this does not CREATE the user id Moodle, it logs in a user created earlier when they enrolled.  The key part of the whole thing is the PK parameter sent by the sending site.  It's HMAC of the entire query string plus a pre-shared key. That validates that the query string came from your partner site. Note also that the hashed parameters include a timestamp. function user_login ( $ username , $ password ) { $ extusername = core_text :: convert ( $ username , ' utf-8 ', $ this -> config -> extencoding ) ; $ extpassword = core_text :: convert ( $ password , ' utf-8 ', $ this -> config -> extencoding ) ; $ teexsso = Teexsso :: getInstance () ; return $ teexsso -> checkhmac () ; } function loginpage_hook () { $ teexsso = Teexsso :: getInstance () ; return $ teexsso -> loginpage_hook () ; } class Teexsso { protected static $ instance ; public $ isvalid = false ; public static function getInstance () { if ( !isset ( self ::$ instance )) { self ::$ instance = new Teexsso; } return self ::$ instance ; } /** * Protected constructor to prevent creating a new instance of the * *Singleton* via the `new` operator from outside of this class. */ protected function __construct () { } function loginpage_hook () { global $ DB ; global $ SESSION ; global $ CFG ; global $ frm ; if ( empty ( $ _GET [ ' PK ' ])) { return false ; } $ this -> username = $ this -> checkhmac () ; if ( $ this -> username ) { if ( empty ( $ frm ) || ( $ frm )) { $ frm = new stdClass ; } $ frm -> username = $ this -> username; $ frm -> password = ' x '; $ this -> isvalid = true ; if ( $ _GET [ ' C ' ]) { $ courseid = $ DB -> get_field ( ' course ', ' id ', array ( ' idnumber ' => $ _GET [ ' C ' ])) ; $ SESSION -> wantsurl = $ CFG -> wwwroot . ' /course/view.php?id= ' . $ courseid ; } } } function checkhmac () { global $ DB ; if ( $ this -> isvalid && !empty ( $ this -> username )) { return $ this -> username; } if ( empty ( $ _GET [ ' PK ' ])) { return false ; } // This must use $_GET rather than _param to ensure variables are from the query string, and therefore in the hmac. // We wouldn't want a different username set via POST. $ hmactry = $ _GET [ ' PK ' ] ; $ this -> username = $ _GET [ ' username ' ] ; $ time = $ _GET [ ' T ' ] ; if (( !$ hmactry ) || ( abs ( $ time - time ()) > 600 )) { return false ; } $ key = 'RANDOM_STRING_YOU_MUST_CHANGE_THIS '; $ paramstr = preg_replace ( ' /&*PK=[A-Za-z0-9]+/ ', '', $ _SERVER [ ' QUERY_STRING ' ]) ; $ paramstr = preg_replace ( ' /^\?/ ', '', $ paramstr ) ; $ hmaccorrect = strtoupper ( hash_hmac ( ' sha256 ',' ? ' . $ paramstr , $ key )) ; if ( $ hmactry !== $ hmaccorrect ) { $ this -> isvalid = false ; return false ; } $ this -> isvalid = true ; if ( !empty ( $ _GET [ ' txid ' ])) { $ txiduser = $ DB -> get_field ( ' user ', ' username ', array ( ' idnumber ' => $ _GET [ ' txid ' ])) ; if ( $ txiduser ) { $ this -> username = $ txiduser ; } } global $ user ; $ user = get_complete_user_data ( ' username ', $ this -> username ) ; return $ this -> username; } } Be very, very careful - it's easy to get authentication wrong, and it is a target for attack.  The above code, while written by a security professional, has not yet passed my own final security analysis, much less third-party review.

ResponsesInList.Text: Having the server in the DMZ means you'll need to configure your firewall to let the Moodle server 'talk' to your domain controller servers in the internal network, which might need to open a bunch ports. Saludos. Iñaki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NTLM doesn't work when the Moodle server is in the DMZ

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NTLM doesn't work when the Moodle server is in the DMZ
ResponsesInList.Text: LDAP authentication just needs port 389(TCP) and optionally port 636(TCP) if you want LDAP+SSL. But NTLM SSO needs the whole 'SMB/Kerberos dance' with several ports, possibly including 88, 137, 138, 139 (some of them TCP & UDP) and probably others. Have a look at your firewall logs to see what traffic is being blocked from your Moodle server to your internal domain controllers. That should give you a clue. By the way, I wouldn't do this myself unless you really know what you are doing. It opens up a big vector for all kind of attacks when (not if) your Moodle server gets compromised. Saludos. Iñaki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Email-based Self-Registration

Maybe CentOS 5.4 has SELinux enabled by default and the Web server (httpd) is not able to connect to the winbind socket. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: User attribute switching (ldap)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tyler, if you change user attribute in your Moodle DAP authentication plugin, there are good chances that the attributes content are different and Moodle will not be able to match against LDAP existing user anymore, thus creating a new account. In Moodle 2.4 you can prevent new user account creation setting to true "Prevent account creation when authenticating | authpreventaccountcreation" however you still need to update existing Moodle user profiles to allow matching of the new user attribute.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: User attribute switching (ldap)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tyler, to update your existing users you could try " Upload user" function, where you can also update your accounts. To change username when uploading, you need to use the the special field "oldusername" so Moodle will be able to match users. Steps could be: 1) download your user using Bulk user actions 2) edit your CSV file with new values - remember to keep the "oldusername" column and specify the new ones - 3) upload user updating existing accounts. When uploading, make sure you selected the option that allow usernames change. I strongly suggest to double check the procedure and results on a test server before attempting anything on your production environment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Email - based self registration with Admin approval
ResponsesInList.Text: After trolling through the forums on this topic and plenty of ideas I have successfully implemented a self - registration with Admin approval without altering too many core / library files and introducing any security risks(!). I thought I would share this with the community. Please note you will need to have access to the core / library files possibly through ftp . Here's how the code works: 1. Prospective user requests an account (login/signup.php) 2. User is greeted with a custom message saying their request has been sent to administrator (login/signup.php). No email is sent to the user. 3. An email is sent to administrator about the new account request. Its achieved by redirecting the email to the admin instead of the user (lib/moodlelib.php). 4. Administrator views the user (admin/user.php) and manually confirms the account. On clicking ‘confirm’ the new function send_confirmation_email_to_user gets triggered and sends an email to the user. The email only contains a message stating their account has been confirmed and no activation links are sent. Procedure: The main idea is to not send the activation links during the email exchange. So the only way to confirm someone's account is by the administrator's doing this manually (which requires admin rights). Here are the changes I made to the three files: 1. lib/moodlelib.php [changes made to send_confirmation_email($user) function] Removed activation / confirmation links from being generated - line 5939 Email sent to $supportuser instead of $user - line 5947 Made necessary changes to library files for the custom messages sent to site administrator. 2. lang/en/moodle.php - added two new strings emailconfirmation_user and emailconfirmationsubject_user on line 562 3. admin/user.php - Added a new function send_confirmation_email_to_user($user) - line 3 - changed strings emailconfirmationsubject_user and emailconfirmation_user - Added send_confirmation_email_to_user($user); line 101 to call the function when account is manually confirmed. Please do fully test this before implementing on a live server . Any suggestions to make this better would be greatly received.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Authentication Plugin Changes not Reflected in the Database
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a quick question about storage of authentication plugin settings: Where do they go? If for example I save the hostname test.hostname.local into the CAS server configuration page at "server/admin/auth_config.php?auth=cas" and then check for its value in the moodle database within the table: mdl_config_plugins, I see that the value has been updated. But, if I change this value directly in the database, it is NOT reflected in the site administration page. This almost suggests that this setting is saved in two places.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Authentication Plugin Changes not Reflected in the Database
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Jeff, you are probably using a Moodle version that includes the MUC (Moodle Universal Cache ). This component caches a great deal of information to speed up many operations (including access to the DB). So it may happen that as you are not doing any changes to the setting through the Moodle code, the MUC still holds the (previous) cached, value as it assumes it's still "fresh" (valid). And when the config screen asks for the setting value from the DB, the MUC returns that value. You can purge (invalidate) the caches by going to Administration >> Site Administration >> Development >> Purge all caches Saludos.
Iñaki.

ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. That did the trick.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Will is be possible to migrate authentication?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Yes, you can. If you have few users you can do it by hand, by editing the users and changing the authentication type. If you have lots of them, you can run an SQL query in the database to change the 'auth' column of the mdl_user table. But if you do the latter, make sure you set the 'admin' user authentication to 'manual' (unless you actually want your admin user to use LDAP authentication too). Saludos,
Iñaki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto Authentication With MS Server 2003 step by step guide?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rich, I think what you want is something called LDAP - this will allow Moodle to authenticate users to against the domain, so they'll use the same username and password to log on to Moodle as they used to log on to the computer. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto Authentication With MS Server 2003 step by step guide?
ResponsesInList.Text: Rich, There is a third party plugin for NTLM (NT Lan Manager).  This uses the MS protocol to log folks into Moodle based on thier AD usernames and passwords. How much do you know about Moodle admining? NTLM is very similar to LDAP authentication, but it allows for the browser to send the user data without sending the user to a log in screen.  See this thread about the settings for LDAP. Internet Explorer is compatible with NTLM, to make Firefox compatible you need to edit the configs.  Type about:config into the address bar in FireFox then set the value of network.automatic-ntlm-auth.trusted-uris to the name of the moodle server you want to use ntlm. Hope that gets you started. Good luck, Miguel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LDAP AUTH aNd Batch Upload Users
ResponsesInList.Text: Stuart I have the MySQL addition loaded and using this I selected the mdl_users table (to check the values) and the SQL Tab to enter the code. I then typed in: UPDATE mdl_user SET auth = 'ldap' WHERE auth = 'manual' AND password = '' The check for the blank password picked out accounts which either had been LDAP prior to my upload or which were uploaded with a blank password. It excluded accounts such as guest and admin which need to remain manual. WARNING Take a backup of the database before running an UPDATE query like this. Unless you are certain of the command it may not select the rows you were after You can check with the following code: SELECT * FROM mdl_user WHERE auth = 'manual' AND password = '' Hope this helps Steve

If I login to the PC and open a browser ( IE ), I get logged into Moodle automatically. If I then open a new browser window it too will go to the configured homepage where i then get a "You are already logged in as USERNAME, you need to log out before logging in as different user. I have investigated a bit and I am thinking that this is either my-user error as I am pushing the wrong homepage out via group policy OR I have not setup the session system correctly. I have tried database sessions and PHP sessions and also seen a forum post of giving Domain Users RW access to the PHP session folder. All of these don't seem to make any difference. I did wonder if I had to investigate memcached or even try and do a redirect in the <SITE>/login/index.php but I would prefer to avoid code hacks if at all possible to help with future code upgrades. I was wondering/hoping if anyone else has come across this issue and possibly would have any suggestions? Tested this on Server 2008, IIS7, PHP 5.4.24, Moodle 2.7.2+ Server 2008, IIS7, PHP 5.4.14, Moodle 2.5.1+ Server 2003, IIS6, PHP 5.4.42, Moodle 2.9.1 Many thanks for any help anyone can give. Ian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NTLM SSO - "You are already logged in"
ResponsesInList.Text: It is the directing to <MOODLESITE>\login\index.php that is causing the problem. You don't need to. They just need to try and visit any page requiring authentication which will kick off SSO. Exactly which page this is depends on your authentication settings. So on our site there is no guest or access for unauthenticated users so if you go to <MOODLESITE> that kicks of NTLM SSO and signs you in. If you open a second window and go to <MOODLESITE> that picks up that you are already signed in and doesn't just try and sign you in again. The problem is in using the login page. If you visit that when you are already logged in then it gives that message, regardless of how you logged in.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Switched authentication from file upload to LDAP, merging accounts?
ResponsesInList.Text: Merging account activity is possible, but I wouldn't fancy the task. The way I dealt with our transition was to make users aware of the issue and wherever possible alter existing accounts before the LDAP accounts were created. I wrote a script to do this more easily than drilling into individual users' accounts; taking the old username and the new LDAP username, a function made sure: there was no existing account with the 'new' username there was an existing account with the 'old' username the 'old' account did not already use LDAP! and then the new username and auth type were set in the table. This way the (now LDAP authenticated) user keeps their enrolments, activity logs, message history etc. You are welcome to a copy, but bear in mind it was written for 1.6 and has hard-coded postgresql queries that would probably need changing for mysql .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Authenticating users from other sites to Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! I tried to go about doing a similar thing. I started by reading the following and following the steps to go about creating the basic authentication plugin. It uses my own way of authentication via checking the incoming password's hash against a secret hash key. http://docs.moodle.org/en/Authentication_FAQ Once I had done that moodle accepted my user's login details but still remained the issue of creating users who weren't already on moodle's internal database. It would prompt the user coming in to create their profile on moodle once they had logged in. Now since that is work duplication for the user(He/She has already logged in through my external site and shouldn't have to do so again), I had to think of something to avoid that and bypass the new user registration. I wanted moodle to use my user's existing credentials on the external site to be passed onto moodle and moodle should just accept those and create the user automatically. The result should be the same user being logged in as him or her in moodle home page. Once the requirements were clear I looked at the authentication API http://docs.moodle.org/en/Development:Authentication_API NB: By this point I had a basic auth plugin which implemented the mandatory function user_login() So moodle calls this when going through all the auth plugins and checks if the user checks out. ~Once that happens it also looks for any user information - name, email address, and other credentials to populate it's database(especially if the user does not exist on moodle yet), that it does by calling an optional function in the auth plugin called get_userinfo($username) - Refer to API above. Note that The api says auth_user_login() and auth_get_userinfo(), they have changed in moodle 1.9 to just user_login($username, $password) and get_userinfo($username). So I implemented the get_userinfo($username) in the auth plugin and in there I basically defined it in a similar way to the get_userinfo() method in the 'FC' auth plugin ( You should be able to find the existing code in your moodle install /auth/fc/auth.php.) $fname = $_REQUEST['fname']; if(isset($fname)) { $userinfo['firstname'] = $fname; //moodle db key firstname } the other moodle db keys are lastname, email, country, city, you could probably look the rest of the keys up in the moodle db itself using phpmyadmin for custom credentials. So I got the credential first name from the REQUEST Object(*) which was passed from my external site as part of the POST request as a hidden parameter alongside username and password. *Had a php script on my external site which sent the username and password to the moodle login website http://moodlecomputer/login/index.php as a POST action page for a form with input elements such as username, password, email, and other credentials needed for moodle to make the new user on its internal database. So the auth plugin picks up the information as above and when get_userinfo() is called by moodle it creaes the user with those credentials, job done!

ResponsesInList.Title: Authenticating with LDAP/s using our internal CA
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is the scenario. We have a hosted VPS with inmotionhosting. We've acquired root access and currently have moodle installed on one of the user cPanels. We've hired a SME to customize moodle to our liking. The problem is trying to setup LDAP /s authentication for the purposes of creating users. Since the moodle server is located on a VPS and we went the route of using our internal CA for authentication, we had to open port 636 on our firewall and allow communication from the VPS public IP. Once that was done we went about configuring the LDAP module in moodle. Here are our settings for the LDAP server (note that there is an internal host entry on the VPS for the host URL specified below): Host URL: ldaps://server.contoso.local Version: 3 Use TLS: No LDAP encoding: utf-8 Hide Passwords: Yes Dstinguished name: CN=svc-Moodle,OU=Svc,DC=contoso,DC=local Password: password User type: MS ActiveDirectory Contexts: ou=sd users,dc=contoso,dc=local Search subcontexts: Yes Dereference aliases: No From our CA, we exported our CA cert and imported it into the VPS. We used this moodle doc to then attempt to establish a link using that certificate: http://docs.moodle.org/26/en/LDAP_authentication#Enabling_LDAPS_on_your_Moodle_server From an SSH shell into the VPS, here are the exact commands we used to try and establish the secure link: cd /etc/ssl/certs openssl x509 -in <ca cert name>.cer -inform DER -out <ca cert name>.pem -outform PEM openssl x509 -in <server cert name>.cer -inform DER -out <server cert name>.pem -outform PEM c_rehash cat <ca cert name>.pem | grep 'BEGIN.* CERTIFICATE' | wc -l openssl x509 -noout -fingerprint -in <ca cert name>.pem openssl x509 -noout -hash -in <ca cert name>.pem ln -s ca_drsdc3.pem `openssl x509 -hash -noout -in <ca cert name>.pem`.0 Then to verify the certs were installed correctly, we used these commands: openssl verify -verbose -CApath /etc/ssl/certs /etc/ssl/certs/<ca cert name>.pem openssl verify -verbose -CApath /etc/ssl/certs /etc/ssl/certs/<server cert name>.pem They returned an OK. The final step was to use this command to verify that we can connect and authenticate successfully with our internal CA: openssl s_client -connect server.contoso.local:636 This is where the problem lies. This is the output from this command: root@vps11666 [/etc/ssl/certs]# openssl s_client -connect drs-dc3.drsystems.local:636 CONNECTED(00000003) depth=0 CN = DRS-DC3.drsystems.local verify error:num=20:unable to get local issuer certificate verify return:1 depth=0 CN = DRS-DC3.drsystems.local read:errno=104 I'm not an openssl expert by any means, but I can see that there are verification problems when connecting to our server. Does anyone have any ideas on how to help us?

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm about to kick off a small pilot of Moodle using 30 or so users with manual accounts ahead of us buying in an MIS integration package that will run in conjunction with LDAP authentication. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Users moving from Manual to LDAP - what is best practice?
ResponsesInList.Text: The easiest way to change the authentication type from "manual" to "ldap" for a lot of users is to update the auth column on the mdl_user table in your Moodle database . For all users: UPDATE mdl_user SET auth = 'manual'; For one user: UPDATE mdl_user SET auth = 'manual' WHERE username = 'whatever'; If you're switching from MANUAL authentication to LDAP authentication then you don't need to do anything with the password - Moodle will use the users LDAP password for authentication. But going from LDAP to MANUAL might be more tricky...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing AD Users via LDAP
ResponsesInList.Text: I think this is normal behavior, our setup certainly behaves that way. The ldap lookup is after all only an authentication method, so it's merely checking the details supplied by the user against the ldap/AD database . Here a student logs into Moodle the first time and creates a Moodle profile, the ldap connection checks with AD about whether the student is allowed to login to Moodle then creates the account on Moodle, this means that Moodle doesn't have to store all the passwords etc and users have a common password for logging into the computer and using Moodle. If the password is changed in AD it changes automatically in Moodle. In practical terms if a user is in AD they can use Moodle but will still have to create a Moodle profile the first time they login. There are companies I've seen that claim they can offer a tighter level of Moodle<->AD integration where users can be imported, but I think primarily these are just a scheduled task that runs every so often and creates Moodle profiles based on the ldap account details rather than anything more. So my feeling has always been is it worth the extra cost for such integration when an AD user can login to Moodle anyway, it just takes a couple of extra minutes the first time around. John Gifford

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing AD Users via LDAP
ResponsesInList.Text: That is the way it is supposed to work.  When they log in, Moodle will query LDAP and create a profile according to the fields that you have specified in the settings.  If you map all the required profile settings, then it is a seamless process for the user and they do not even know what is happening in the background. The only issue that I have found with this is that you cannot enroll a student in a course until after first login so that is where the csv upload comes in.  Yes, you can specify LDAP for the authentication method and so that works well.  Another step for the admin but I actually use the same file to add new users to LDAP and then Moodle. I am not sure if anyone has come up with an LDAP sync plugin yet but you might search the plugins.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing AD Users via LDAP
ResponsesInList.Text: There is a php script in Moodle that will allow you to sync users from AD.  You must have LDAP authentication setup. Before you run the script make sure your LDAP is pointing to the OU with user accounts only. If not, it will sync computer objects and become overwhelming. I suggest you setup a cron job to have the script run automatically. The script is located at /var/www/moodle/enrol/ldap/cli/sync.php

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Javascript to strip @email.edu from logon
ResponsesInList.Text: Janet: Below is our patch. We made it because username and username@SeattleAcademy.org were being treated is two separate users, but both authenticated against our IMAP server . This was creating multiple accounts. You would not use this in the case of a site that wanted to allow domain names to be part of their usernames. In the file /login/index.php Find: $frm->username = $user->username; Below that, paste: if($atPos = strpos($frm->username,'@')) $frm->username = substr($frm->username,0,$atPos); Below that, we also add: if($atPos = strpos($frm->username,'\\')) $frm->username = substr($frm->username,$atPos+2,strlen($frm->username)); We do the last statement because users can also login as SeattleAcademy\\username, so we just use the last part. Good luck! --Gary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LDAP Authentication on moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: If your new moodle server really can't see the LDAP server you were using before, then you can just change the auth type to be manual on each user, and set a password. You could change the auth type flag in the database from 'ldap' to 'manual', using SQL , but that wouldn't set a password for each user (unless you have password caching enabled on the old moodle, so the LDAP password is stored in the db you imported, then make sure the config.php as Emma said matches up. Particularly if you have a password salt set on your old moodle config.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LDAP Authentication on moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: You cannot just import a database from one Moodle to another without also bringing across the Moodle code (at least the config.php file) and going through the full migration steps.  Or did you do that? What you might do is enable manual authentication on your existing site and then migrate it again.  That should allow you to at least login to the new site with a local admin account and then make whatever changes that you need.
